descriptions.location: This hidden room is equipped like a scientific laboratory. Various experimental paraphernalia sits on a large cluttered table. On one wall is a huge chart covered with spidery handwriting.

descriptions.detailed: It takes a few moments to decipher the erratic script, but you soon realise that this is a family tree, of sorts. It reaches back more than a dozen generations and covers the main Bray family line. Four names are underlined, each three generations apart. Peter Bray (born 1559 – died 1601), Alfred Bray (born 1645 – died 1703), Hugo Bray (born 1749 – died 1794), and Cecile Bray (born 1862). All appear to be the first born child in their generation.
The table is a mess. A tangle of rubber pipes and glass vials, half-melted candles and jars filled with strange-coloured liquids.
descriptions.contains.bray.portrait: Also on the table is a framed picture of a girl.
descriptions.contains.bray.desk-key: Sitting on the table is a small key.

descriptions.detailed: This is a small portrait of a young woman in an ornate gilded frame. She is beautiful, but appears somewhat sad. Around her neck is a delicate looking golden chain from which hangs a tiny golden heart.
This is a small key, it does not look big enough to unlock a door, but appears well-suited to be used with a piece of furniture..
